componenttextpreview: I guess you always have that potential, Rob. A couple of things going on, one, there is a definite desire but I know on the hill [ph] to have those supplementals baked into the budget. That has been a stress point for years, and I expect that to continue.
componenttext: I guess you always have that potential, Rob. A couple of things going on, one, there is a definite desire but I know on the hill [ph] to have those supplementals baked into the budget. That has been a stress point for years, and I expect that to continue. On the other hand, the demands are increasing, in the short term anyway, both because there's operations that have been carried out in both Pakistan, and there is probably some level of effort going on in Yemen as well. And you have the Iraq elections that will happen next month, which will be an indicator of how stable and ready we are to transition and hand over operating control security, really, of the country. So there's a lot of factors, but there certainly is the potential for them to increase in the short run of the course. As...

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and the reason I asked the question is what we're hearing is there is a lot of upward pressure. The second slug of FY '10 may exceed expectations, the peace associated with the Afghan surge, and therefore for FY '11. On that note, I'd like to segue i
componenttext: Yes, and the reason I asked the question is what we're hearing is there is a lot of upward pressure. The second slug of FY '10 may exceed expectations, the peace associated with the Afghan surge, and therefore for FY '11. On that note, I'd like to segue into the other question, which has to do with ISR aircraft. If you could talk a little bit about specifically the opportunities, how we should think about the complexities? You mentioned there are common sensor before. There's EPX, which has had a lot of headwind. How do you see the landscape evolving here? What are the other opportunities for Project Liberty-type ISR, et cetera?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again Rob, I'll try to get as specific as I, can but really what you're seeing is a general trend. Of course, a number of things, ACS is just one indicator. I think you could EPX, the proposed EPX, the successor to the EP-3 in the same camp is that.
componenttext: Well, again Rob, I'll try to get as specific as I, can but really what you're seeing is a general trend. Of course, a number of things, ACS is just one indicator. I think you could EPX, the proposed EPX, the successor to the EP-3 in the same camp is that. And that trend is to rely more on both the UAVs and the small aircraft ISR, given the current position we are in as a nation and the conflicts that we're dealing with. In terms of the -- right, we're not just using fighters, we're using ISR. So it's a totally different mission to gather this information. And to operate in the theater as required needs numerous sensors and processing capability, data links, ground terminals, you name it. So that is a trend that we expect to continue that has been driving, and we expect to continue to drive the ISR space. And the most specific example I could give you was on the Aerial Common Sensor transitioning to this EMARSS capability, which is another small aircraft-based proposed ISR system. But I would say watch carefully what happens with EPX, whether that gets funded or that mission dissipates to UAVs and other small aircraft.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's what I was going to as you. Because I think that mission, EPX, may be gone next week. And does that migrate into something that's even more in your wheelhouse?
componenttext: And that's what I was going to as you. Because I think that mission, EPX, may be gone next week. And does that migrate into something that's even more in your wheelhouse?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as you know, the requirement is still there to do maritime surveillance and controls. There's other ways to do it, I guess. And it certainly does work in our space very well, both from a sensor capability, from many things we do. As you know, it's th
componenttext: Yes, as you know, the requirement is still there to do maritime surveillance and controls. There's other ways to do it, I guess. And it certainly does work in our space very well, both from a sensor capability, from many things we do. As you know, it's the sensors, the data links. It's the integration of the airframes. It's ground stations. It's the microwave capability gathering processes. And we kind of have end-to-end capability on the whole intelligence gathering, processing, dissemination, archiving chain. So it is a potential for us, certainly.

componenttextpreview: No, we see Rivet Joint actually continuing as is for quite sometime. And we look at this all the time because it is so important to us. And I dread to ask the question when is the Rivet Joint going to get replaced. But it really is not on the table at all
componenttext: No, we see Rivet Joint actually continuing as is for quite sometime. And we look at this all the time because it is so important to us. And I dread to ask the question when is the Rivet Joint going to get replaced. But it really is not on the table at all. And it's probably good for about a decade, given some of the upgrades that have been. At least a decade, I guess, for the way that it operates. But again, that's a broader theater type of system.

componenttext: Mike and Ralph, one of the things that I've noticed just in conversations with investors about L-3 is that there are several items, and you've mentioned some of them, pension and SOFSA extension and so on, that allow one to take the previous guidance and to say, well, it looks like it could be a little bigger. And I was wondering whether where's the softness that you mentioned? I mean, is this intended to be a cushion? Or is this just -- I mean, it's a little bit confusing about why not put things that seem pretty obvious and hedge things that seem more uncertain in terms of the way people are thinking about it? It seems to me there's a reasonable number of people that somehow or other think that the number should be 8.50, not 8.

componenttext: No, listen, the softness in the plan both last year and looking forward is in the services area. And we're really waiting, one, to see what the funding profiles is going to come out of some of these programs. We also have the potential of the drawdown in Iraq hurting that sector even more. So that is the downside. And the hedge is things like JOG going out a little further.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: So it just seems that people should be careful before they add things that look easy in because some of the other things are harder to call and have been a little less talked about. Just to prevent people from getting ahead of the -- 8.20 seems reasonable.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: That's exactly right. And we do provide quarterly updates on as we go through the year on it, as we see things develop more. But there has been no change in our philosophy or strategy in how we give our guidance. It's the same as it's always been, and in a less clear and less certain environment. So you don't need to get factored in. The predictability, if it was 95% two years ago, I would tell you it's probably 85% or 80% now. So there is a little less predictability just to [ph] the environment.

componenttext: Brian, like I said in my commentary, we think our margin guidance is conservative, and we can try to do better. In terms of where we think we're going to have the most improvement, it's going to be in the C3ISR segment. And the margins in '09 were very strong in Electronic Systems. And we're being conservative there in particular.

componenttextpreview: Yes, and as a follow-on to the previous question, we're deliberately being conservative, particularly in the Government Services segment. One of the things I said at the investor conference last month was that in '09 we were continually surprised by weakn
componenttext: Yes, and as a follow-on to the previous question, we're deliberately being conservative, particularly in the Government Services segment. One of the things I said at the investor conference last month was that in '09 we were continually surprised by weakness there, and we had to lower the guidance on the top line two or 3x. And we don't want that to happen again this year. And I think that's reflected in the guidance.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you just give us an update on what you're looking at for Iraq and Afghanistan revenues in 2010 and maybe kind of walk us through those contracts?
componenttext: Could you just give us an update on what you're looking at for Iraq and Afghanistan revenues in 2010 and maybe kind of walk us through those contracts?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, the sales estimates in the 2010 guidance for both Iraq and Afghanistan are essentially unchanged from what we talked about at the investor conference, which calls for about $800 million in Iraq and about $350 million in Afghanistan. The Iraq work is
componenttext: Sure, the sales estimates in the 2010 guidance for both Iraq and Afghanistan are essentially unchanged from what we talked about at the investor conference, which calls for about $800 million in Iraq and about $350 million in Afghanistan. The Iraq work is comprised of ISR and Intel support activities at about almost $200 million, about $150 million in training and law enforcement work. I talked about $120 million for Linguist, and the balance would be equipment maintenance on the CFT, CFS programs and some sales related to SOFSA. The balance is about $200 million or so in a variety of product areas, namely communication terminals, some EO/IR turrets and the Tactical Quiet Generator or TQG. What's in the Afghanistan sales estimate is about $50 million for contract sales services, another $50 million for special operation forces support, $40 million for intel support, and then the rest of it is trading and law enforcement activities. And we talked about the upside that we think we have on the training side in Afghanistan, but that is going to require us to win a competition. And there's one currently going on right now. We want to wait and see what happens before we increase the guidance we expect at the training work there.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, just on Electronic Systems, where specifically are you being conservative? What particular business lines do you think that there's upside?
componenttext: And then lastly, just on Electronic Systems, where specifically are you being conservative? What particular business lines do you think that there's upside?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we're continuing to be conservative in the simulation device area, also in propulsion systems. That's the two areas that we have surprise funding cuts or order delays last year. On the display side, we're assuming the business is pretty flat. There
componenttext: Again, we're continuing to be conservative in the simulation device area, also in propulsion systems. That's the two areas that we have surprise funding cuts or order delays last year. On the display side, we're assuming the business is pretty flat. There's the military side. You don't have a lot of new aircraft builds going on to the U.S. Military right now. And then we were continuing to be cautious about the commercial business outlook. In fact, we're assuming that the commercial business has declined by about $100 million this year versus 2009, most of that in the shipbuilding products area.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro with Access 342.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you follow-up the comment that we were talking about at the conference in terms of M&A and how you see that versus what's clearly an attractive stock price?
componenttext: Can you follow-up the comment that we were talking about at the conference in terms of M&A and how you see that versus what's clearly an attractive stock price?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're taking a balanced view, George. As I said, we have been reluctant over the past couple of years because of the disconnect between our trading multiple and what acquisitions cost. I mean you've seen it in play, where we certainly leaned heavier on sh
componenttext: We're taking a balanced view, George. As I said, we have been reluctant over the past couple of years because of the disconnect between our trading multiple and what acquisitions cost. I mean you've seen it in play, where we certainly leaned heavier on share repurchases than acquisitions. But we see opportunities where that gap is closing. And I thought about that discussion because it is a very fundamental discussion on how we look at it. And some of it is science, but a little bit of it is art too. And I would say that if we we're in a situation, another I would say it, where the market is discounting aerospace and defense companies to the extent it has been 30% to 40% below the S&P multiples and a good company were to come along, would we just turn the other way and not pursue it even though it's in the long-term interest of L-3 to buy it? It's almost like cutting off your nose to spite your face in the sense that because the market's being inefficient or out of sync at the moment, that as you preclude an M&A deal that makes sense now. Having said that, we haven't crossed that line because we haven't seen one that does make sense to stretch for. And as I said previously in this discussion with you, we can debate this all year, I'm sure. But that gap has closed significantly in a lot of places that we're looking. So where it does make sense.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one little thing for Ralph, you said Ralph that $800 million sales in Iraq didn't change, but why wouldn't it have gone up to $100 million that you added for JOG to go through May?
componenttext: And then just one little thing for Ralph, you said Ralph that $800 million sales in Iraq didn't change, but why wouldn't it have gone up to $100 million that you added for JOG to go through May?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Because only a small portion of what we do on JOG relates to Iraq.
componenttext: Because only a small portion of what we do on JOG relates to Iraq.

componenttext: Well, I mean, yes. I mean, can you talk about the market size and the opportunity that you see because unseating incumbents is not easy to do and this is, I think -- I mean, the fact that you culled it out means that it's not trivial.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, but sizing these markets are hard to do, absent a budget at the moment. Obviously, there are important spaces for us that we intend to continue to focus on and grow. I can tell you that unseating incumbents is difficult. On the other hand, the view in
componenttext: No, but sizing these markets are hard to do, absent a budget at the moment. Obviously, there are important spaces for us that we intend to continue to focus on and grow. I can tell you that unseating incumbents is difficult. On the other hand, the view in this administration towards sole-source is not a good and more things are getting competed but not. So you're going to see more shifting of contracts around the industry. You're going to win some. You can probably win more and lose more as a result of that. I mean, that's just a fact of life. So I would tell you that our view is embodied in our guidance and the overall growth that was showing in ISR in certain product areas, such as our EO/IR and aircraft mod. Actually, if you look at that segment and you take the effect of JOG out, it's actually growing about 5%. And we view that as a market that we would like to see steadily grow for us because of the lack of new platforms and the need for upgrade and sustainment on existing. So both of them are growing markets, but trying to put a number around it is not something that I certainly have the ability to do right now.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I understand that, but it I mean it puts additional hours in your quiver that you haven't had before, and there is probably some other competitions that come along now that you have some bonafides that you didn't have before. Is that fair?
componenttext: No, I understand that, but it I mean it puts additional hours in your quiver that you haven't had before, and there is probably some other competitions that come along now that you have some bonafides that you didn't have before. Is that fair?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's absolutely true. That's a good way to look at it, Howard. And also, when I said we're looking more M&A this year, we're looking to add capabilities in these spaces that further our ability to compete better. So that is true.
componenttext: That's absolutely true. That's a good way to look at it, Howard. And also, when I said we're looking more M&A this year, we're looking to add capabilities in these spaces that further our ability to compete better. So that is true.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then kind of taking that same theme, you've been kind of bumped on the head a little bit with the Bradley transmission business. Where is that -- and man ground vehicle has been entirely disrupted, but at some point, don't you have again a capability
componenttext: And then kind of taking that same theme, you've been kind of bumped on the head a little bit with the Bradley transmission business. Where is that -- and man ground vehicle has been entirely disrupted, but at some point, don't you have again a capability of sort of recouping that and this capability doesn't go away? I mean, how are you approaching that market and some of the, I'll call it changes in the Army vehicles?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Howard, it's couple of things. One, the requirement hasn't gone away. You have Bradleys that need transmissions. The reason for the shift in funding  and the bump on the head, as you called it, was that Bradleys were not being used in Afghanistan, so it w
componenttext: Howard, it's couple of things. One, the requirement hasn't gone away. You have Bradleys that need transmissions. The reason for the shift in funding  and the bump on the head, as you called it, was that Bradleys were not being used in Afghanistan, so it would no longer was a priority and the funding was moved to other miniature [ph] priorities. Now there is also a recognition that DoD, as said by Secretary Carter, Secretary Lynn and Secretary Gates that industrial base is important. We are the only supplier of transmissions to Bradleys. So I'm not yet ready to go knock on doors and say, "Hey, if we don't order some, we're not going to have them anymore because we can't afford to keep the plant open." It's just the volume issue right now. We expect the funding to eventually come back in that space. Now when you look at the broader vehicle market, it's certainly a space where L-3 would like have a bigger presence, and doing that in a way that did not necessitate us going out by a vehicle company. We're starting one because obviously that is not bet that we think is in the interest of our shareholders. But we also see opportunities in areas like electric propulsion. We have introduced our Integrated Starter Generator that is being trialed now on some of the vehicles that would've been in the form of future combat system but more than the new HumVee, as a matter of fact, as well suspensions. We're looking at the potential for assimilating some electronic components to come up with what I would refer to as a common vehicle electronics suite. So it's common from vehicle to vehicle. It's a debate whether that's vehicle-driven or soldier-driven. Where somebody comes in and plugs in their own device that takes care of things like GPS communications, night vision, threat detection and the like. So there's a lot of electronic content that could be developed and inserted in the family of new vehicles, and that is certainly a space that we will continue to look at and get into. And our electronic-actuated log [ph] transmission suspension systems are getting more noticed now because of the up armoring of everything. It's coursing center of gravity and tipping issues. So the Electronic Controlled Suspension System (sic) [Electronically Controlled Active Suspension System] or ECASS is starting to get a serious look as well. So there is upside there, but it's been a long road to get any traction in this area.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, our final question of the day comes from the line of Michael Lewis with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, our final question of the day comes from the line of Michael Lewis with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I read the draft QDR yesterday, Mike. The theme throughout the document was the use of a ground, air and underwater unmanned vehicles. And so we know where you stand with regard to the aerial systems. I want to know if you could size your market opportuni
componenttext: I read the draft QDR yesterday, Mike. The theme throughout the document was the use of a ground, air and underwater unmanned vehicles. And so we know where you stand with regard to the aerial systems. I want to know if you could size your market opportunity for us on the ground and underwater unmanned vehicle marketplace. And what's out there in front of you right now?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well any of the -- that's a hard one because there are no real programs that I'm aware of in unmanned vehicles of any significance. And the undersea areas that we've been involved with have to do with untethered mine detection vehicles, which have been ve
componenttext: Well any of the -- that's a hard one because there are no real programs that I'm aware of in unmanned vehicles of any significance. And the undersea areas that we've been involved with have to do with untethered mine detection vehicles, which have been very small to date. Now not having the benefit of reading the QDR as you have, it's hard for me to envision that as being a driver in both under the sea and land in the short term, but in the long-term, it could be a significant driver for us just because of the components and subsystems that we would have available and potentially even developing our own vehicle in that sense because we've done that on the airborne side with our Mobius and UAV Viking product. So that would include again the traditional data links, comp systems, bounce [ph] stations, et cetera. But it's hard to put anything around it without any real programs of record yet in that space.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on Government Services, what is the pricing environment look like? Are you seeing any situation to where the government's coming in with a reverse auction-type methodology on pricing for contracts?
componenttext: Just a quick question on Government Services, what is the pricing environment look like? Are you seeing any situation to where the government's coming in with a reverse auction-type methodology on pricing for contracts?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't. I could give a little color in that space. As you know, there were a couple of things going on last year. One, there was the concern about how the government would apply OCI rules that prevented some benefiting on certain work across the i
componenttext: No, we haven't. I could give a little color in that space. As you know, there were a couple of things going on last year. One, there was the concern about how the government would apply OCI rules that prevented some benefiting on certain work across the industry. Number two, there was a concern about what was known as the in-sourcing of contracts, where the stated objective of adding 30,000 to 40,000 people to the DoD would be taken from industry. There's been some clarity in those two areas. One, the OCI legislation that have been served up from the Hill is probably not going to be what gets done, which was very onerous for both the DoD and industry to live with. In fact, you saw a significant divestiture last year from one of the major players in that space. So there will be guidance that should come out, as I recall, next week. They said around February 1, that we think the DoD and the industry can live with. And with that clarity, we should be able to move forward a little bit better. In addition to in sourcing, well, at least 10,000 of those jobs have to do with cost estimators, contract specialists, accountants, attorneys, et cetera, that are not coming from the industry. In fact, they're new hires that are coming out of the non-contractual world [ph]. So that's taking a little pressure off of us on that as well. In terms of the competitiveness, I think that the government doesn't have to do anything because everybody in the industry seems to be showing up for every competition because the air was getting a little thin. And that aspect of it's been taking care of itself. Now having said that, our margins have been relatively stable, enough [ph] services, and has to do with the top of the type of services we offer, which I would call more in the non-commodity type work. It's not just body shop work, if you will. It's very specialized work, whether it's Military training, nation building or it has to do with some of the clearance cleared work that we do for the three-letter agencies or some of the scientific engineering work that we do in the U.S. I mean, this is a special workforce that we have. So we're able to pretty much not have to drop off pricing into the 3% and 4% range as you might see on our typical IT contracts. So I think our services will stabilize this year. We're hopeful to see how it develops throughout 2010.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I thank you for joining us. And again, it's still January. There's both tailwinds and headwinds this year. Last year only looked like headwinds when we had this call a year ago, and there were concerns persisted about the future of spending. I think
componenttext: Well I thank you for joining us. And again, it's still January. There's both tailwinds and headwinds this year. Last year only looked like headwinds when we had this call a year ago, and there were concerns persisted about the future of spending. I think I would characterize the environment that we're operating in as stable. There are shifting priorities, and it's getting more and more important to look at below the top line and what the individual areas that are going to get funded in go-forward will include. As we've been saying, I think we are well positioned to do well in this environment, and we look forward to talking to you in the second quarter and providing further updates. So thank you.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for joining us for L-3 Communications First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. We me are Michael Strianese, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Ralph D'Ambrosio, Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. After th
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for joining us for L-3 Communications First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. We me are Michael Strianese, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Ralph D'Ambrosio, Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. After their formal remarks, management will be available to take your questions.
Please note that during this call, management will reiterate forward-looking statements that were made in the press release issued this morning. Please refer to this press release, as well as the company's SEC filings for a more detailed description of the factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Please also note that this call is being simultaneously broadcast over the Internet.
I will not turn the call over to Mike Strianese. Mike, please go ahead.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I hope everyone has had a chance to read the earnings release. We had a good start to 2010, with a solid first quarter. Our earnings per share were up 13% to $1.87 per share, and that's even
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I hope everyone has had a chance to read the earnings release. We had a good start to 2010, with a solid first quarter. Our earnings per share were up 13% to $1.87 per share, and that's even after a $0.04 per share charge related to that Medicare Part D prescription drug coverage compared to 2009's first quarter.
Overall, although sales were essentially flat at $3.6 billion, our ISR business continued to do very well, with significant growth offsetting declines in the other segments. ISR grew at approximately 11%. The flatness in sales were attributed to orders and sales that have moved from the first quarter out into probably the second quarter. Most notably, our order for the additional JCA, the Joint Cargo Aircraft, expected in March has moved out of the quarter, probably will come in the second quarter.
So at the end of the quarter, March 31, our backlog was at $10.8 billion. First quarter orders were $3.6 billion, which gave us a book-to-bill of 1. But that's even without this $233 million JCA order, so we are happy with the book-to-bill at 1. 
We had some significant wins in the quarter, several which we're competitive, including a NAVAIR systems engineering support contract and a U.S. Air Force Cybersecurity operations contract, as well as linguist services for a classified customer. We also had significant follow-on orders on several important legacy programs, including our UAV Communications Systems, EO/IR charts, our ROVER product, Phoenix communications systems, our Compass Call aircraft, the Canadian F-18 program, the Law Enforcement Professionals program, our Contract Field Services, maintenance work at Fort Rucker, the small ISR aircrafts such as Project Liberty, Rivet Joint work, U.S. Navy P-3s, AVCATTs and to the C-12 CLS, just to name a few. 
In terms of recompetitions, the only major outstanding recompete for us continues to be the Special Operations Support for support activity contractor JOG. Where that stands today is that SOCOM is currently taking corrective action in response to our protest. They said they expect to release a new RFP in April and make an award by next January. As of now, we still haven't received RFP. But in the meantime, the period of performance on our contract, the incumbent contract, has been extended to January 31, 2011. And our contract value has been increased by $400 million. We expect to see a new contract in this competition being worth up to $5 billion over 10 years, and this is obviously a very important program to us. And we await this competition and look forward to continuing on this, the incumbent of course. 
In terms of our significant programs, I'll name a few. In terms of the larger ones, I can give you some color. First of all, on JCA, the Joint Cargo Aircraft, we expect orders for eight aircraft during the fiscal '10 budget, which will bring our orders to date to 21 aircraft. Now that's the order that I mention slipped out in the first quarter, but we still expect it. It's in the budget, so we expect to see the money. I think it's a paperwork issue. We also expect eight more in fiscal '11. So the total U.S. Air Force buy is expected to be 38 aircraft with the final nine coming in fiscal '12.
This year, we expect to deliver four JCAs, bringing total deliveries inception to date to six. We've already delivered in the first quarter two of those four. So we're in good shape to make those deliveries this year. In addition, the National Guard is still projecting a need for additional aircraft and there's also a potential for a plus up in fiscal '12. So we remained optimistic on this program. And obviously, there's still several foreign military sales opportunities. I would not characterize them as being in the short term just because the sales cycle is longer internationally, but as this aircraft begins to get deployed, we expect to see more interest in it.
In terms of Project Liberty, we are modifying, as you know, a total of 37 MC-12W aircraft for the U.S. Air Force. So far, we've delivered 23 aircraft on time, on budget, and our deliveries are surpassing our contractual schedule. We expect to finish delivering all 37 aircraft this November. Not only was Liberty the fastest delivery by a defense contractor for our weapon system to the U.S. military since World War II, but also the aircraft's performance to date has been truly exceptional. We're very proud of the performance here. The fleet has flown more than 2,100 sorties over 7,000 hours with a mission availability rate exceeding 96%.
We look forward to continuing to fly L-3's expertise to other small aircraft ISR applications, both with the DoD, as well as international customers. For example, we currently expect the Air Force to expand the Liberty fleet by six airplanes, hopefully, later this year or fiscal '11. And several international customers are expressing strong interest. So there's a lot of activity in this space.
As you know, the Army is also proceeding with a competitive procurement for what's known as the Enhanced Medium Altitude Reconnaissance Surveillance System or EMARSS. And that's an aircraft that focus on a regular warfare missions, communications, intelligence, electro-optical/infrared missions and communications. The EMARSS configuration will be a small aircraft similar to the Liberty MC-12 platform. Draft RFP was already released and the final RFP is expected next month, with the contract award likely by the end of September. The initial buy is expected to be about six, probably four aircraft, I'd say, and could grow to 36 aircraft for the full program, the initial contract. L-3 is competing for EMARSS as a prime.
The U.K. Springtime contract, just remember, that was once known HELIX, now Springtime. The good news with Springtime is that the U.K. Ministry of Defense and the U.S. Air Force are going forward with the program. The letter of authorization for this foreign military sale was signed by the MOD and the U.S. Air Force last month in March. And as you know, we were selected to be the prime. 
It will be a significant program for L-3 with over $700 million over the next seven years. It consists of three U.S. Air Force RC-135 aircraft to replace the U.K. Nimrod, ISR Intelligence Surveillance & Reconnaissance aircraft. Although the program is going forward, which is a good news, it has been delayed per the LOA that was signed with the first delivery slipping 12 months to April 2014. We expect to begin negotiating our contract with the MOD soon, with the award happening we expect no later than the first quarter of 2011 and quite possibly later this year. And we could receive a long lead materials contract by the second quarter this year, which we are in.
So we expect to provide three Rivet Joint U.K. versions, plus ground training and training equipment. The logistics since sustained, part of that program will be provided under a separate agreement. So our scope today is the aircraft integration including the ISR and mission data systems installation, logistics services and sustainment.
Finally, the Whole Body Imaging product for airport checkpoint is finally getting a little bit of wind behind it. As we've previously said in December of 2009, we received the five-year IDIQ contract from the TSA, valued at up to $167 million depending on quantities ordered. In the first quarter, we also booked about $17 million of orders from international customers. The TSA is expected to deploy 300 of these systems soon. Today, there are only two qualified suppliers, it's L-3 and another company. Our system relies on millimeter wave, and it's not an X-ray. 
This morning, I'm pleased to tell you, we received the TSA order for the first 202 systems valued at $31.7 million. So they're drawing down on that IDIQ. The Whole Body Imaging situation is unfolding and we continue to keep you posted as those evolve. So I would be very hopeful that once they are deployed and used in airports, and hopefully, they will take advantage of the automated screening and there is no actual imaging or privacy concern. The travelers will become more comfortable. It will speed lines in airports and it will pick up the demand. I expect there to be at least the market for 2,000 of these systems, if not more. And you can define that market as every lane in every terminal in every airport. So it's a big market and we're optimistic that this will start to pick up speed as we go forward.
There's been a bunch of buzz in the press about the tanker opportunity with EADS. As you know, L-3 is always interested in expanding our program base when our capabilities are a good match. And we're also very eager to form strategic partnerships with regards to our business. This sounded like a potentially interesting opportunity for us, and we were considering a subcontractor position. We did evaluate carefully the opportunity and decided not to proceed being part of the team. The scope of work was not something that typically we would do in our Mission Integration business and it really didn't fit anywhere else for us. But the door is not closed forever. There's always an opportunity to start talks again someday. And of course, we still work with EADS on a number of other opportunities and wish them well in the competition. 
In terms of new business opportunities for 2010, other new business opportunities, what we're seeing generally is just a slippage of things by month, not by years, but the paperwork process, competitions, funding is delayed somewhat. So the EMARSS and Springtime programs I just talked about, you can see they moved little bit to the right. The Counter-Narcotics Afghan Police Training program competition is also been delayed because of a competitor's successful pre-award protest. It appears the Army may have to conduct a full and open competition pushing the award to the second half of 2010. 
Linguist, we're still waiting for INSCOM to issue the RFP for the worldwide linguist. Recompetition, the RFP, has been expected to be released in February. The new contract is expected to be a multiple award IDIQ and is now expected to be awarded in the fourth quarter of this year. So again, you can see things moving to the right in several places.
Other areas would be the Department of State Civilian Police Training program, C-17 training system sustainment contract, the U.S. Army C-12 contract logistics services competition and the Army CECOM S32G competition. That one is slipping until next year and will likely be broken into three to five elements. So not only is it going to slip, but it's going to be broken into smaller pieces.  The actual timing of these awards will be impacted by protest and other procurement delays, potentially, but we'll keep you posted on our quarterly calls and our press releases, of course.
In terms of capital deployment and acquisitions, this quarter, we repurchased $123 million of our stock in the first quarter. Our authorization that remains is about $300 million, and we expect to complete it this year, before the end of the year. With respect to acquisitions, we continue to evaluate several companies. Apparently, we have some very good opportunities and expect to invest more dollars in 2010. 
As you know, we announced the acquisition of Insight Technology and closed it last week. We think it's a great fit. As you know, we've been very selective in what we acquire. And it's been slow in the last couple of years because of the lack of qualified candidates in the general business environment. But I'm happy to say that Insight is the perfect type of acquisition that we look for. It broadened significantly our capability in EO/IR and Warrior Systems. And in fact, we are creating a new segment in our Electronic Systems area called L-3 Warrior Systems. It will be a $700 million operation that will include Insight, as well as our EOS or Electro-Optical Systems business, our Infrared Products business and EOTech business. And it accomplishes many of the things I've talked about regularly such as synergy among our pieces, getting better guide to our customers, consolidating and developing best-of-breed products. 
We're delighted that Ken Solinsky, who is the Founder and President of Insight, is staying with L-3 and will lead our new sector, known as Warrior Systems. The types of products and technology include laser aiming lights, target pointers, tactical illuminators, laser range finders, night vision devices, thermal imaging system, sensor fusion and a host of others. And again, we're very, very pleased to have completed this transaction in the first quarter or slightly after the first quarter. And we hope that we'll be able to announce a few more this year as well.
Overall, in terms of our liquidity and capital resources, our balance sheet continues to be very strong, as well as our liquidity position. As you know, within the last year, we were upgraded to investment grade if need to access the capital markets, particularly that debt market for a larger transaction, not much larger, but a larger transaction, we certainly could.
As you know, in our release this morning, we updated our 2010 guidance, increasing our earnings per share range to $8.13 to $8.33, that's up 8% at the midpoint. We expect to see sales between $16.2 billion and $16.3 billion. That's up 4% at the midpoint. The major increases to the guidance relates to the extension of the SOFSA contract, and for the full year now and the Insight Technology acquisition as well. We also have some upside from winning some of the new business opportunities I discussed earlier and from deploying more of our cash in strategic ways that will also increase our earnings.
The only item I could talk about is since the last call, the DoD budget was finalized, as well as the QDR. And our view is the budget remains healthy and robust, modest-based budget growth plus a large overseas contingency operation supplemental. As you know, Iraq and Afghanistan will continue to determine the near-term resource decisions. 
As for the QDR, the Quadrennial Defense Review, it emphasizes the key objectives centered in the fiscal '10 proposed budget by Secretary Gates. And I view it as a balancing document. If you saw with the premise that our current core structure is more geared towards conventional or near peer type of warfare. You would look at this QDR as being a document that would balance that structure to one that's more towards today's engagements, meaning, asymmetrical regional warfare, willing to take a little bit of conventional risk and prepared to fight the fight we're going for. And you see that in the programs that we are working on. Notably, things like Liberty, the EMARSS competition and the training programs in Afghanistan. I mean that has become obviously the major focus. And looking to tomorrow's potential conflict, that's the way things are being structured. 
And we think that works very well for the way L-3 has put together in terms of our business areas, notably ISR, Electronic Systems. Both of them address these areas very well in terms of the things we do. And our services with the nation-building military training services, among others that we provide in the intelligence area and the AM&M taking today's platforms and making them more relevant for tomorrow's threats or taking small aircraft and converting them to ISR platforms quickly, rapidly, rapid deployment, these are all things that will be important as we go forward. So we are very confident with the L-3 business model going forward.
The budget, as you know, contains few new starts, and we expect to see some rationing and reprogramming to continue. But again, we think reprogramming areas, we are very strong player. 
So overall, I think the portfolio of businesses in L-3 and our capabilities, as well as the quick reaction culture that we demonstrated in the Project Liberty and other programs are very well positioned for the new evolving DoD QDR priorities. And with that, let me turn it over to Ralph to give you some of the financial details and then we'd be happy to take your questions. Go ahead Ralph.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. I'll highlight some trends about the first quarter results or give you the changes to our 2010 guidance and finish with some comments about our March balance sheet.As Mike said, overall, we had a very solid strong first quarter, which w
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. I'll highlight some trends about the first quarter results or give you the changes to our 2010 guidance and finish with some comments about our March balance sheet.
As Mike said, overall, we had a very solid strong first quarter, which was underscored with our diluted earnings per share of $1.87, which was up 13% or $0.21 over last year's first quarter. And the main driver of that EPS growth was higher margins. With respect to sales, in the first quarter, consolidated sales declined $12 million or about 0.3% to $3,624,000,000. 
C3ISR, that segment grew 11% and that growth was offset by declines in our other three segments. In those three segments, sales for the first quarter were about $70 million less than we expected due to a variety of delays on several programs and products, including Joint Cargo Aircraft, WIN-T, EP-3, eXaminer and Whole Body Imaging detection systems, CSEL terminals and also a large classified IT services contract that we competitively won end of last year, for which the start date moved to April because of a protest by an incumbent.
Another factor which also unfavorably impacted the first quarter sales growth rate is that when you look at all of our negative sales comparisons for 2010 versus 2009, they are more pronounced in the first half, and those include Linguist, the Army CECOM task orders and the Bradley Fighting Vehicle. 
Now getting back to the segments, sales in Government Services declined 6% or $64 million, and that was driven by two items: Lower subcontract passthroughs on the Army CECOM SSES task orders, reduced sales by $45 million; and the Linguist Iraq subcontract, sales declined $22 million.
In Aircraft Modernization and Maintenance, sales were down about 2%. JCA was one of the main drivers there, which declined $6 million. And JCA sales were actually $25 million less than we expected for the first quarter because of the slip in the FY '10 aircraft award that Mike talked about.
In Electronic Systems, sales declined 1%. And what happened there was that growth in EO/IR Microwave Communications simulation and training in undersea warfare was offset by declines in Combat Propulsion Systems, due primarily to the Bradley Fighting Vehicle and also declines in our Marine & Power Systems business areas, driven by the lower commercial ship building product sales and also lower U.S. Navy sales on the Virginia-class submarine. Also, sales of security and detection systems declined $12 million, and that was due mostly to lower international eXaminer sales. And what happened there was shipments that we planned for the first quarter slipped into the second quarter because the customers were simply not ready to receive the equipment. And lastly, Mike talked about the WBI order or Whole Body Imaging Systems, that was also delayed on the first quarter, and we're happy to have booked that order today.
Moving on to operating margin, consolidated margin was very strong, reaching 11.3%, up 100 basis points over the first quarter of 2009. Margins expanded significantly both in C3ISR and Electronic Systems. We had improvement in contact performance, meaning, direct labor and material costs, and continue the discipline on reducing overheads, plus better higher profit margins in the sales mix. Additionally, we had some favorable items which occurred early, including a contract modification adjustment and a supply agreement volume price adjustment. Those two improved the margins in the first quarter.
So the first quarter margins were unseasonably high for Q1. And we don't expect to repeat those 13% plus margins in those segments, C3ISR and Electronic Systems, for the balance of this year. Margin was weaker than expected in government services on couple of timing items concerning an award fee and a contract award. And we also had an unplanned charge on a security systems contract, which reduced the margins there by 40 basis points. But overall, we continue to make very good significant progress on our operating margins.
Free cash flow for the quarter was also very strong at $245 million, up $133 million compared to the first quarter of last year. Now moving on to the changes to our 2010 full year guidance, we raised EPS by $0.13 on both the high end and the low end of our range, making the new EPS range $8.13 to $8.33. Three items primarily caused the increase: First, the acquisition of Insight Technology, which was completed on April 14, that will add $0.12; the contract extension on SOFSA, taking it beyond May in our guidance, for the full year adds $0.05, and those were offset by $0.04 charge on the new healthcare law that was enacted last month. 
We increased our sales guidance by $400 million to $16.2 billion at the low end and by $300 million to $16.3 billion at the high end. At the segment level, we increased sales by $200 million in Electronic Systems for Insight and $200 million for the SOFSA extension and the Aircraft Modernization and Maintenance segment. We tightened the consolidated sales guidance range by $100 million because of the store slower start in the first quarter and we also were on guard against any continued order and funding delays.
Consolidated operating margin was increased by 10 basis points to 10.8% due to the strength in C3ISR and Electronic Systems, and that strength is more than offsetting reduced margin expectations and the other two segments. Aircraft modernization and maintenance is down a bit because now we'll have SOFSA for the full year. And in government services, the pricing environment continues to be very challenging. Now the tax rate was increased 30 basis points, also related to that healthcare law. And our free cash flow guidance was raised slightly by $10 million to $1.26 billion. 
Finally, looking to the second quarter, we expect sales to be about $4 billion, with EPS of about $1.90 and free cash flow of about $200 million. Similar to the first quarter, we expect to have a challenging top line growth situation in the second quarter and that's due again mostly to those negative sales comparisons for the full year compared to 2009, which are more pronounced in the first half.
A couple of comments on the balance sheet. We ended March with $1.1 billion of cash, and we expect that to be about the same when we get to the end of the year after we pay for Insight due $500,000 share repurchases and pay our dividend. That will leave us with ample cash for more share repurchases and/or more business acquisitions. Overall, we think our balance sheet is very strong and that we have ample liquidity and cash to pursue growth opportunities. 
That concludes my comments, and we'll now go to the Q&A.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010

componenttextpreview: In light of the award delays that we're seeing, what do you look for, for book-to-bill in the second quarter? And what's your guess as to where it might be for the year?
componenttext: In light of the award delays that we're seeing, what do you look for, for book-to-bill in the second quarter? And what's your guess as to where it might be for the year?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cai, we're looking to a book-to-bill of 1 for the year, that's in our guidance. Although it probably won't be a line driver for the next three quarters. If everything had slipped in the first quarter, obviously, catches up in the second, we'll see it high
componenttext: Cai, we're looking to a book-to-bill of 1 for the year, that's in our guidance. Although it probably won't be a line driver for the next three quarters. If everything had slipped in the first quarter, obviously, catches up in the second, we'll see it higher. Any additional wins that have been factored that would cause, especially ones that are more backloaded towards the end of the year where there's no immediate deliveries, would cause the number to go up as well. So we're comfortable where we are right now, projecting at least a 1 for the year and obviously, we're working hard to try to beat that.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your second quarter guidance really assumes a big dip in margins, given that you had some abnormal factors in the first quarter. Could you give us just some color in terms of the pattern of margins as we go through the year?
componenttext: Your second quarter guidance really assumes a big dip in margins, given that you had some abnormal factors in the first quarter. Could you give us just some color in terms of the pattern of margins as we go through the year?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: As I said, the margins that we had in the first quarter were unseasonably high for L-3. Typically, we have our weakest operating margins in the first quarter and then they improve sequentially throughout the balance of the year. But like I said, the combi
componenttext: As I said, the margins that we had in the first quarter were unseasonably high for L-3. Typically, we have our weakest operating margins in the first quarter and then they improve sequentially throughout the balance of the year. But like I said, the combination of those funding delays and a lot of it was on lower margin-type work, including JCA, plus the early favorable items that we had planned for later in the year, which happened in Q1, those drove the margins up in the first quarter. That said, the margins are still a little better than we expected. And for that reason, we took the margins up 10 bps for the full year to 10.8. And as we always do, we're going to try to do better. We just don't want to commit to it yet. But when you get to the second quarter, I think our quarterly margin trends are going to resume with what you've seen in the past, Cai.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we should expect the second to be the weakest and the third to be better and the fourth to be better just in terms of a general matter for the year?
componenttext: So we should expect the second to be the weakest and the third to be better and the fourth to be better just in terms of a general matter for the year?

componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

componenttextpreview: Mike, you mentioned the scope on the tanker really wasn't the right fit. Could you elaborate a little?
componenttext: Mike, you mentioned the scope on the tanker really wasn't the right fit. Could you elaborate a little?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we evaluate -- first of all, Rob, we love to team, we love to be with these two teams, we love to be on both teams on a competition, and we certainly are happy to do work with these. We supply equipment on the A300 Series of airplanes in terms of CC
componenttext: Well, we evaluate -- first of all, Rob, we love to team, we love to be with these two teams, we love to be on both teams on a competition, and we certainly are happy to do work with these. We supply equipment on the A300 Series of airplanes in terms of CCAs and flight recorders. In this particular instance though where it would've involved our Mission Integration division, which is where we're cranking out Liberties, bidding on EMARSS, have the Springtime programs ramping up and have a limited amount of hangar space in capacity. But it's really not space, it's more resources personnel-wise. We did a business evaluation and thought that the scope that we would've liked to have seen would've been bigger for us to commit to that program. Now I'm not to say that it doesn't end up there someday, but where it was during the time that we were looking at it, it was just something we typically wouldn't do in terms of committing our Mission Integration division's resources.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Also on aircraft, JCA, is there any risk to this order, this fiscal '10-funded slug that we've been talking about here?
componenttext: Also on aircraft, JCA, is there any risk to this order, this fiscal '10-funded slug that we've been talking about here?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Rob. I wish I could say absolutely not. I believe it's absolutely not. It's in the budget, and the planes are in production, if I'm not mistaken. I mean, you can't wait for the airplane and start screwing things together. So Again, I don't have a good
componenttext: No, Rob. I wish I could say absolutely not. I believe it's absolutely not. It's in the budget, and the planes are in production, if I'm not mistaken. I mean, you can't wait for the airplane and start screwing things together. So Again, I don't have a good explanation nor do I think any of my colleagues towards the industry of why some of these orders are slipping from where they should have landed. But I'm not expecting to see slip much longer. I mean we're planning this in the second quarter. And as I said, for the four deliveries this year, two of them were already made. So as you know, we like to manage these programs tight, stay ahead of everything. And we did do a big in advance on Liberty as well where we won advancement contract that provide materials and things to make sure that we were able to meet the rapid delivery that the customer is looking for, and we're on the same page here. So the answer is no. There's been no indication that there's anything that would cause me to think it's in jeopardy. But there's unforeseen things, about 100% positive, but I have no reason to believe it's not coming in the second quarter.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the only reason I asked, Mike, it might be too far along for it matter. It's just the dichotomy here at Air Force's versus Army and the real appetite that the Air Force has for these planes to begin with, no fault at all to you guys, it's just this
componenttext: Well, the only reason I asked, Mike, it might be too far along for it matter. It's just the dichotomy here at Air Force's versus Army and the real appetite that the Air Force has for these planes to begin with, no fault at all to you guys, it's just this idea that the C-130 is there and available and this program has shrunk. DO you see where I'm getting at?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, of course I do. I mean we had a firm commitment to 37 airplanes. The money is in the budget. And we fully expect it to be funded. I guess you always run the risk of a contract program termination but we haven't heard anything like that. That's not no
componenttext: Yes, of course I do. I mean we had a firm commitment to 37 airplanes. The money is in the budget. And we fully expect it to be funded. I guess you always run the risk of a contract program termination but we haven't heard anything like that. That's not nothing that we are planning on. In that scenario, we'd be reimbursed for most of the things we spent money on. So I hear you, but that we haven't got the win to that all.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010

componenttext: And the last thing I would just ask you to comment on is, General McChrystal has been out there saying there's too many contractors in theater. You've got some there. And do you make anything of that? Is there going to be an effort here to try and pressure that number down?

But the way things are getting broken up, you're going to have more companies running around the theater of operations because everything going to task order in smaller pieces.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think some of them are probably in there in advance of the surge. I think the surge is halfway through, and there's additional 30,000 troops. There's about 15 there now. I don't know how to respond to that, Rob, because I don't know that people si
componenttext: Well, I think some of them are probably in there in advance of the surge. I think the surge is halfway through, and there's additional 30,000 troops. There's about 15 there now. I don't know how to respond to that, Rob, because I don't know that people sitting around doing nothing is a very demanding environment. There's Contract Field Teams there to keep the equipment running, whether it's helicopters, or land vehicles, or UAVs or ground electronics and the like. So I gather they're okay there. The training is something that is our exit strategy. So as training both the Afghan National Army, as well as the police force is something that is a precursor to the U.S. withdrawal. So I think that those services are necessary. And those areas that are of interest to us. If there are other places where there are too many people running basis and mess halls and things like that, I'm certainly sure they don't want to waste the money and they'll withdraw them. We have no indication of that in anything we're doing, though.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, for Mike, can you give a feel of how you look at '11 in the C3 area, given that Project Liberty is ending, and EMARSS is a potentially big contributor? Can you kind of size how you look at that business, with and without the win for EMAR
componenttext: And then finally, for Mike, can you give a feel of how you look at '11 in the C3 area, given that Project Liberty is ending, and EMARSS is a potentially big contributor? Can you kind of size how you look at that business, with and without the win for EMARSS next year?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, EMARSS would be a great win for us, and as I said, it could be actually the next Aerial Common Sensor, for all we now. So that would certainly be incremental or additive. But even without EMARSS, our core business is extremely solid in this area. Un
componenttext: Well, EMARSS would be a great win for us, and as I said, it could be actually the next Aerial Common Sensor, for all we now. So that would certainly be incremental or additive. But even without EMARSS, our core business is extremely solid in this area. Unabated demand for 24/7 full-motion video is not going away, even in drawdown situations. That is a force multiplier that allows the remaining troops in place to stay safe and know what's going on. So I don't see that impacting us dramatically in terms of drawdown. The Rover product, for example, is still in production. We're going up to version six of Rover. And I see no slowdown there as well. When you take a look at Liberty, we think that even though we'll be delivering the 37th aircraft in November that there's the opportunity for several more orders another six or so. And there's additional capability that's being looked at based on the current fleet that's operating. Again, that's a new airplane doing special missions. And the operator's coming back with their experience with it in Zangie [ph] that we had this change, some of it's in the classified space. There's a potential to refit the existing 37 with advance mission systems, whether we drop things in in-theater or they comeback. So I view this as a long tail in this business area. It's consistent with what's in the budget. It's consistent with the strategy set forth for the QDR that the C3ISR area will continue to be a major focal area. And finally, the technology, George, in this space is moving quickly, whether it's smaller, faster, lighter, different waveforms, wider band, you can imagine the networks that are in place now. The demands on bandwidth are incredible. So it's driven by a bunch of things, the environment, the engagements, obviously, the technology changes and the threat environment. So we feel very solid about the ISR business going forward

componenttext: I'd give you a wide range. I would say eight on the low end, maybe 12 to 15 on the high end. I'm happy at around 10. But let's call it eight to 12. And I think I'm comfortable in that bandwidth.

componenttext: What happens when you get into next year, while we complete the deliveries in 2010 this year and into next year, we're going to be ramping up our CLS work, the logistics support. So for that reason, the revenue is going to remain pretty steady. It might be down a little bit, but if we get those six additional airplanes...

componenttext: If you get the six airplanes, then it will be...
